docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's request that Congress slow the growth of Medicaid, a centerpiece of the White House budget for 2006, is drawing opposition from some Senate Republicans, who are caught between their desire to support the president and pressure from home-state governors resisting the cuts. One Republican, Senator Gordon Smith of Oregon, said he would call for a commission to examine the finances of Medicaid, the government insurance plan for the poor, in an attempt to generate bipartisan proposals about how to rein in the soaring cost of the program. Another, Senator Mike DeWine of Ohio, said he was worried about the impact Medicaid cuts would have on his state. A third, Senator Norm Coleman of Minnesota, said he was not ready to sign off on cuts.

headline.main: Some G.O.P. Senators Resist Proposed Medicaid Cuts

docs.abstract: Pres Bush's request that Congress cut Medicaid costs is opposed by some Senate Republicans who are caught between supporting Bush and supporting governors resisting cuts; Medicaid cuts are part of overall goal to reduce spending on so-called entitlement programs and face strong resistance from state politicians; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Some Senate Republicans are caught between their desire to support the president and pressure from home-state governors resisting the cuts.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to a nationwide settlement of certain class-action lawsuits over prices that patients without adequate health insurance were charged for prescription drugs, products and services at hospitals owned and operated by Tenet subsidiaries. The settlement is subject to certain conditions, including court approval, Tenet said. The company is based in Dallas.

headline.main: TENET HEALTHCARE SETTLES SOME SUITS OVER CHARGES

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDICAL malpractice litigation reform is a high priority for President Bush, who contends that juries are running amok, multimillion-dollar settlements are on the rise and greedy trial lawyers are filing frivolous suits. The results, Mr. Bush and others argue, include skyrocketing insurance prices, abandoned medical practices, defensive medicine and a crisis of access to care. Their proposed solution: caps on jury awards to patients and on lawyers' contingent fees. No one disputes that insurance premiums have risen significantly. The question is whether a crisis in states' tort systems accounts for the increase. Consider Mr. Bush's home state of Texas, America's second most populous state and the third largest in terms of total health care spending. After studying a database maintained by the Texas Department of Insurance that contains all insured malpractice claims resolved between 1988 and 2002, we saw no evidence of a tort crisis. Adjusting for inflation and rising population, we arrived at the following findings:
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Bernard Black, Charles Silver, David Hyman and William Sage comments on Pres Bush's priority of medical malpractice litigation reform, calling for caps on jury awards to patients and on lawyers' contingency fees; sees no evidence of tort crisis in Texas, and advises against tampering with Texas tort system (M)
docs.snippet: MEDICAL malpractice litigation reform is a high priority for President Bush, who contends that juries are running amok, multimillion-dollar settlements are on the rise and greedy trial lawyers are filing frivolous suits. The results, Mr. Bush and...

byline.original: By Bernard Black, Charles Silver, David Hyman and William Sage

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, there was more evidence that the world has begun edging away from the dollar. International data showed that several more nations who have been big customers for American debt -- including China and India -- have diversified their portfolios away from the American greenback. To us, that sounds like a serious threat to the long-term soundness of the national currency. But the Bush administration hasn't come close to addressing any of the economic fundamentals that have helped spawn the dollar's decline (the budget deficit comes to mind). Instead, the White House has been busy lobbying for new tax cuts that will make the situation worse. Meanwhile, in a world in which the United States desperately needs international cooperation on everything from curbing the trade in terrorist weaponry to presenting a united front to countries like Iran and Syria, President Bush is spending his political capital on getting John Bolton, a longtime critic of multilateralism, as representative to the United Nations.
docs.abstract: Editorial expresses concern that Pres Bush does not appear to be rethinking his goals during his second term, with next campaign no longer an issue; finds that, with so many crucial problems facing nation, Bush seems determined to ignore biggest challenges, and concentrate on politically charged side issues; contends Bush administration has not come close to addressing any of economic fundamentals that have helped spawn dollar's decline; contends, instead, White House has been busy lobbying for new tax cuts that will make situation worse; cites other issues that Bush administration is not handling well, such as financing of Medicare and Social Security
docs.snippet: The president seems determined to ignore the biggest challenges and to home in on politically charged side issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States economy expanded at a moderate pace from late January through February, with few signs of inflation despite rising production costs, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday. ''The economy has continued to expand at a moderate pace,'' the Fed said in its summary of regional economic conditions known as the beige book.

headline.main: The Fed Says All Is Well, Or Mostly So

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve's beige book report shows US economy expanded at moderate pace from late January through February, with few signs of inflation despite rising production costs; retail prices were generally flat; businesses continued to face rising input costs, and number of districts indicated greater ease in passing along price increases; labor markets across country had been steady to stronger during period, with overall wage gains moderate; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Delphi Corporation, a leading supplier to the automotive industry. said yesterday that it would stop paying medical insurance for 4,000 retired salaried workers in 2007. Delphi will drop coverage for retirees once they become eligible for Medicare, which it will supplement with private health care accounts, the company told employees on Monday in an e-mail message. The move is expected to save the company $500 million over several years. Delphi said it spent about $1.1 billion on health care last year. Delphi, which is based in Troy, Mich., will hire a company to manage the new medical accounts, but it has not selected the company, a spokeswoman, Luce Rubio, said.

headline.main: DELPHI TO CUT MEDICAL INSURANCE TO 4,000 RETIREES

docs.lead_paragraph: MBIA, a financial services conglomerate that guarantees billions of dollars in bonds, said yesterday that it was restating its financial results for the last seven years because of improper accounting related to two insurance deals it struck in 1998. The restatement, which amounted to a $54 million net reduction in profit over the period, is related to financial reinsurance agreements MBIA made with Converium Re, a reinsurer previously known as Zurich Reinsurance Centre.

headline.main: MBIA Will Restate Results for 7 Years Over Improper Accounting

docs.abstract: MBIA is restating its financial results for last seven years because of improper accounting related to two insurance deals it struck in 1998; restatement, which amounts to $54 million net reduction in profit over period, is related to financial reinsurance agreements MBIA made with Converium Re, reinsurer previously known as Zurich Reinsurance Centre; MBIA says restatement will not have material impact on its financial position (M)
docs.snippet: This could be first of many restatements as companies recheck insurance agreements.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at the financially troubled Westchester Medical Center, who last month urged all levels of government to come to its rescue, say the 1,000-bed regional hospital will deplete its cash reserves within months. In an interview about the hospital's fiscal woes and future prospects, the interim president and chief executive, Mary Brown, and the hospital board's chairman, Richard A. Berman, said that without continuing government support, the hospital would continue to lose money. The deficit for last year is estimated at $56 million and this year's is projected at $60 million.

headline.main: Westchester Hospital Says It Must Have Government Money to Survive

docs.abstract: Westchester Medical Center (NY) interim president Mary Brown says that without continuing government support, hospital will run out of money within months; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Officials at the financially troubled Westchester Medical Center say it will deplete its cash reserves within months.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials are not enforcing a law that requires drug companies to cut their prices on drugs bought for poor people under Medicaid, Congressional investigators said on Monday. The investigators, from the Government Accountability Office, said the federal Medicaid agency rarely verified the accuracy of price data reported by drug manufacturers and used to compute the discounts required by law. As a result, they said, Medicaid, the nation's largest health insurance program, with more than 50 million beneficiaries, often pays too much for prescription drugs.

headline.main: Report Says Medicaid Overpays for Drugs

docs.abstract: Government Accounting Office investigators assert that federal health officials are not enforcing lw that requires drug companies to cut their prices on drugs bought for poor people under Medicaid; contends federal Medicaid agency rarely verifies accuracy of price data reported by manufacturers and used to computer discounts required by law; finds that, as result, Medicaid often pays too much for prescription drugs (M)
docs.snippet: Federal health officials are not enforcing a law that requires drug companies to cut their prices on drugs bought for poor people under Medicaid, Congressional investigators said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in New York City are more likely to be obese and less likely to exercise than men, which increases their risk of heart disease, diabetes and other ailments that can cut lives short, according to a report to be issued today by the city's Health Department. The report, ''Women at Risk: The Health of Women in New York City,'' focused on an array of issues affecting women's health, including access to health care and cancer screenings as well as behavioral issues, and was based on data pertaining specifically to women that was culled from several surveys in 2002 and 2003.

headline.main: Study Finds More Obesity and Less Exercising Among New York City's Women Than Its Men

docs.abstract: New York City Health Department study finds that women in New York City are more likely to be obese and less likely to exercise than men; graph (M)
